title: Stuart Gallacher
text:
Ian Stuart Gallacher (22 May 1946 – 19 October 2014) was a Welsh <a href="List%20of%20dual-code%20rugby%20internationals">dual-code international</a> <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>, and professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1960s and 1970s.
Rugby union playing career.
Born in <a href="Llanelli">Llanelli</a>, Gallacher played for <a href="Felinfoel%20RFC">Felinfoel RFC</a> and <a href="Llanelli%20RFC">Llanelli RFC</a>, as a <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Locks">lock</a>, i.e. number 4 or 5. He joined <a href="Llanelli%20RFC">Llanelli RFC</a> in 1965, and played almost 200 games for the club. At Llanelli RFC he won his only international cap for <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a>, against <a href="France%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">France</a> on 4 April 1970. He played at invitational level for <a href="Barbarian%20F.C.">Barbarian F.C.</a>
Rugby league playing career.
In 1970, he joined <a href="Bradford%20Bulls">Bradford Northern</a> rugby league club, moving to <a href="Keighley%20Cougars">Keighley</a> in January 1975. He played as a , i.e. number 11 or 12, during the era of contested <a href="Scrum%20%28rugby%29%23Rugby%20league">scrum</a>s. He won <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a>s for <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Wales</a> (RL) while at Keighley in 1975 against France and England, and in the <a href="1975%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1975 Rugby League World Cup</a> against New Zealand, and France.
Rugby union executive.
He acted as chief executive of Llanelli RFC and Scarlets from 1996, before being appointed as chief executive of Regional Rugby Wales (RRW) in 2009. He stood down from the post in June 2014 because of poor health. He was also a member of the board of the <a href="European%20Rugby%20Cup">European Rugby Cup</a>.
